Anyone done much experimentation with processes/threads when backtesting? Obviously hardware specific but with it being CPU bound I find increasing threads above 2 threads results in slower speeds, is this me or have others found he same?

Having profiled (a lot) over the years I know the Available class is the bottleneck, contemplating a rewrite in C...

text: Maybe stating the obvious but have you tried processes instead of threads? I get very nice multi core improvements using `futures.ProcessPoolExecutor`. Over 1000 markets it takes a few mins which is plenty quick enough for me.

text: if the GIL hasn't changed much in the past 10-12 years, thean yeah - GIL won't let you extract more parallelism on multi core machines.  you can get concurrency with threads, but not parallelism unless you go to multiprocessing, or have CPU intensive code in C (or Rust maybe), then you can release the GIL when inside native code

elements.text: if the GIL hasn't changed much in the past 10-12 years, thean yeah - GIL won't let you extract more parallelism on multi core machines.  you can get concurrency with threads, but not parallelism unless you go to multiprocessing, or have CPU intensive code in C (or Rust maybe), then you can release the GIL when inside native code

text: Yep, multithreading in python is only really useful if your threads are waiting on network, disk, etc.  They won’t help with compute-heavy parallelism.  Traditionally in python you’d do this by vectorising your code (e.g. numpy), but backtesting doesn’t really fit into that paradigm all too well.

elements.text: Yep, multithreading in python is only really useful if your threads are waiting on network, disk, etc.  They won’t help with compute-heavy parallelism.  Traditionally in python you’d do this by vectorising your code (e.g. numpy), but backtesting doesn’t really fit into that paradigm all too well.

text: It depends a fair bit on hardware, for example different cores on the same CPU might share certain caches, so sometimes we purposely keep certain cores idle so that other processes get to keep their instructions in a certain level of cache.

elements.text: It depends a fair bit on hardware, for example different cores on the same CPU might share certain caches, so sometimes we purposely keep certain cores idle so that other processes get to keep their instructions in a certain level of cache.

text: Cython backs a lot of scientific/numerical python code (e.g. scikit-learn, pandas, etc) and is pretty easy if you're familiar with a bit of C/C++. You typically don't get a big boost unless you go through and tell the compiler the equivalent C type of variables; It's type inference is pretty weak. But for certain algorithms using the proper data structures, you can get orders of magnitude speed-up and if you're not dealing with actual python objects, you can explicitly release the GIL to get scalable cpu-bound multithreading. Numba is JIT compiles python to efficient machine code, but is primarily for numerical work, so not general purpose, for things like json parsing. As with anything, profile, profile, profile using any combination of cProfile, line_profiler, py-spy, austin, vmprof, etc to find out where the actual hot spots are in the code.

elements.text: Cython backs a lot of scientific/numerical python code (e.g. scikit-learn, pandas, etc) and is pretty easy if you're familiar with a bit of C/C++. You typically don't get a big boost unless you go through and tell the compiler the equivalent C type of variables; It's type inference is pretty weak. But for certain algorithms using the proper data structures, you can get orders of magnitude speed-up and if you're not dealing with actual python objects, you can explicitly release the GIL to get scalable cpu-bound multithreading. Numba is JIT compiles python to efficient machine code, but is primarily for numerical work, so not general purpose, for things like json parsing. As with anything, profile, profile, profile using any combination of cProfile, line_profiler, py-spy, austin, vmprof, etc to find out where the actual hot spots are in the code.

text: The thing with Cython or Numba, is that they can still be slow if a lot of objects are created/destroyed. e.g. if we are creating/destroying a lot of Order objects, or PriceSize objects, the code would still be slow.

user_profile.real_name: Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon
user_profile.name: fcmisc

elements.text: The thing with Cython or Numba, is that they can still be slow if a lot of objects are created/destroyed. e.g. if we are creating/destroying a lot of Order objects, or PriceSize objects, the code would still be slow.

text: So each time a new event is received in the backtest, if we are still creating a lot of objects, we might not get that much benefit from Cython or Numba. But we'd need to do some analysis first, as these things are very dependent on the situation.

user_profile.real_name: Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon
user_profile.name: fcmisc

elements.text: So each time a new event is received in the backtest, if we are still creating a lot of objects, we might not get that much benefit from Cython or Numba. But we'd need to do some analysis first, as these things are very dependent on the situation.
